summary.text:
National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2007 - Authorizes appropriations for the Department of Defense (DOD) for FY2007.

Authorizes appropriations to DOD for: (1) procurement, including for aircraft, missiles, weapons and tracked combat vehicles, ammunition, and shipbuilding and conversion; (2) research, development, test, and evaluation, including ballistic missile defense; (3) operation and maintenance, including for defense working capital funds, the Defense Health Program, drug interdiction and counter-drug activities, and environmental restoration; (4) active and reserve military personnel, including end strengths and the Armed Forces Retirement Home; (5) the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Security Investment Program; (6) chemical demilitarization construction; and (7) Guard and reserve forces facilities.

Sets forth provisions or requirements concerning: (1) active and reserve military personnel policy, including expanded duties for National Guard and reserve members; (2) military education and training; (3) military justice, including an Air Force Office of Special Investigations; (4) military pay and allowances; (5) retired pay and survivor benefits; (6) military health care; (7) acquisition policy and management, including National Defense Stockpile disposals; (8) DOD organization and management; (9) counter-drug activities and matters related to homeland security; (10) civilian personnel matters; (11) matters relating to other nations; and (12) cooperative threat reduction with states of the former Soviet Union.

Military Construction Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2007 - Authorizes appropriations for FY2007 for military construction for the Armed Forces and defense agencies.

National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2007 - Division A: Department of Defense Authorizations - Title I: Procurement - Subtitle A: Authorization of Appropriations - (Sec. 101) Authorizes appropriations for FY2007 for the Army, Navy and Marine Corps, and Air Force for aircraft, missiles, weapons and tracked combat vehicles, ammunition, shipbuilding and conversion, and other procurement.

(Sec. 104) Authorizes appropriations for FY2007 for defense-wide procurement.

Subtitle B: Army Programs - (Sec. 111) Authorizes the Secretary of the Army to enter into a multiyear contract for the procurement of: (1) the Family of Medium Tactical Vehicles, beginning with the FY2008 program year; and (2) 144 MH-60R helicopters and related mission equipment, beginning with the FY2007 program year.

(Sec. 113) Directs the Secretary of the Army to set forth in Army budget materials for any fiscal year after 2007 all amounts for procurement for the M1A2 Abrams tank system enhancement program and for the Bradley fighting vehicle as elements within amounts requested for the Army's Modular Force Initiative, in accordance with a specified Army report.

(Sec. 114) Limits the availability for obligation of funds for the Army's Bridge to Future Networks program until the Secretary of the Army reports to the congressional defense and appropriations committees an analysis of such program and related information.

Subtitle C: Navy Programs - (Sec. 121) Requires Navy combat forces to include not less than 48 operational attack submarines.

(Sec. 122) Provides cost limits, out of Navy shipbuilding and conversion funds, for: (1) the Navy aircraft carrier designated as CVN-21; and (2) any ship of that class that is constructed after the CVN-21. Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to adjust such amounts based upon specified factors, including inflation, changes in federal, state, or local laws, or the insertion of new technology. Allows technology insertion adjustments only if such Secretary makes specified certifications to the defense and appropriations committees with respect to the need for such technology. Requires such Secretary to notify such committees of any ship cost limit adjustments made.

(Sec. 123) Provides a cost limit, out of Navy shipbuilding and conversion funds, for any ship constructed under the LHA Replacement amphibious assault ship program. Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to adjust such amounts based upon specified factors, including inflation, changes in federal, state, or local laws, or the insertion of new technology. Allows technology insertion adjustments only if such Secretary makes specified certifications to the defense and appropriations committees with respect to the need for such technology. Requires such Secretary to notify such committees of any ship cost limit adjustments made.

(Sec. 124) Provides cost limits, out of Navy shipbuilding and conversion funds, for specified San Antonio-class naval amphibious ships. Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to adjust such amounts based upon specified factors, including inflation, changes in federal, state, or local laws, or the insertion of new technology. Allows technology insertion adjustments only if such Secretary makes specified certifications to the defense and appropriations committees with respect to the need for such technology. Requires such Secretary to notify such committees of any ship cost limit adjustments made.

(Sec. 125) Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to enter into a multiyear contract for the procurement of V-22 tiltrotor aircraft, beginning with the FY2008 program year. Prohibits the total number of aircraft so procured from exceeding 211.

(Sec. 126) Directs the Secretary of Defense (Secretary) to prescribe a quality control policy for the procurement of: (1) ship critical safety items; and (2) modifications, repair, and overhaul of such items.

(Sec. 127) Makes specified Navy shipbuilding and conversion funds available for the DD(X) Next-Generation Destroyer program. Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to enter into two contracts for such program, with two different shipbuilders.

(Sec. 128) Expresses the sense of Congress that the Navy should make greater use of alternative technologies, including nuclear power, as a means of propulsion for its future fleet of surface combatants.

Subtitle D: Air Force Programs - (Sec. 131) Prohibits the Secretary of the Air Force, before a specified conditional date, from retiring any B-52 aircraft, other than aircraft with tail number 61-0025. Requires such Secretary to maintain not less than 44 of such aircraft as combat-coded aircraft.

(Sec. 132) Directs the Secretary of the Air Force, as of October 1, 2008, to maintain a total strategic airlift aircraft inventory of not less than 299.

Amends the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) for Fiscal Year 2004 to repeal a limitation on the retirement of C-5 aircraft.

(Sec. 133) Prohibits the Secretary of the Air Force from retiring any U-2 aircraft in FY2007. Prohibits retiring such an aircraft after such fiscal year until 60 days following certification to Congress by the Secretary of Defense that the capabilities provided by U-2 aircraft no longer contribute to mitigating any gaps in intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance capabilities identified in the 2006 Quadrennial Defense Review.

(Sec. 134) Authorizes the Secretary of the Air Force to enter into a multiyear contract for procurement of up to 60 F-22A Raptor fighter aircraft, beginning with the FY2007 program year. Outlines certification requirements with respect to such procurement.

(Sec. 135) Prohibits the number of: (1) KC-135E aircraft retired by the Secretary of the Air Force during FY2007 from exceeding 29; and (2) F-117A aircraft retired by the Secretary of the Air Force during FY2007 from exceeding ten.

Title II: Research, Development, Test, and Evaluation - Subtitle A: Authorization of Appropriations - (Sec. 201) Authorizes appropriations for FY2007 for the Armed Forces for research, development, test, and evaluation (RDT&E). Earmarks specified amounts for the Defense Science and Technology Program.

Subtitle B: Program Requirements, Restrictions, and Limitations - (Sec. 211) Earmarks specified Navy and Air Force funding for continued development of an alternate engine for the Joint Strike Fighter.

(Sec. 212) Extends through FY2010 the authority of the Director of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) to award prizes for advanced technology achievements.

(Sec. 213) Repeals the September 30, 2007, termination date for the Defense Acquisition Challenge Program (innovation and cost-saving technology in Department of Defense (DOD) acquisition programs).

(Sec. 214) Requires the Secretary, after the preliminary design review of the Future Combat Systems program, to carry out a Defense Acquisition Board milestone review of such program, with specified requirements. Requires a report from the Secretary to the defense and appropriations committees on review findings and conclusions.

(Sec. 215) Requires: (1) a comprehensive and detailed cost analysis of the Joint Strike Fighter engine program to be independently performed by the Comptroller General (CG) and the Secretary; and (2) independent cost analysis reports from each such official to the defense and appropriations committees.

(Sec. 216) Earmarks specified defense-wide RDT&E funds to implement or evaluate DD(X) and CVN-21 proposals under the Defense Acquisition Challenge Program.

Subtitle C: Ballistic Missile Defense - (Sec. 221) Allows FY2007 and FY2008 RDT&E funds for the Missile Defense Agency (MDA) to be used for the development and fielding of ballistic missile defense capabilities.

(Sec. 222) Prohibits any DOD funds from being obligated or expended for the testing or deployment of a space-based interceptor until 90 days after a report from the MDA Director to the defense and appropriations committees.

Subtitle D: Other Matters - (Sec. 231) Requires the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics (Under Secretary) to conduct, and report to the defense and appropriations committees on, a review of DOD test and evaluation policies and practices and to issue such new or revised guidance as may be necessary to address emerging acquisition approaches. Requires the Director of the Defense Test Resource Management Center to ensure that the DOD strategic plan for test and evaluation resources reflects any DOD testing needs identified in the review.

Title III: Operation and Maintenance - Subtitle A: Authorization of Appropriations - (Sec. 301) Authorizes appropriations for FY2007 for operation and maintenance (O&M) for the Armed Forces and specified activities and agencies of DOD.

(Sec. 302) Authorizes appropriations for FY2007 for: (1) working capital funds; (2) the Defense Health Program; (3) defense drug interdiction and counter-drug activities; and (4) the Defense Inspector General.

Subtitle B: Environmental Provisions - (Sec. 311) Establishes required qualifications for the DOD position of unexploded ordnance manager.

(Sec. 312) Requires the Secretary to: (1) review historical records to identify the number, location, and size of military munitions disposal sites within covered U.S. waters; (2) at least annually, release information obtained from such review; (3) include such information in a currently-required annual report to Congress; (4) share such information with the Secretary of Commerce to assist the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) in preparing nautical charts and other navigation materials; (5) conduct research on the effects of munitions so disposed; and (6) institute appropriate monitoring mechanisms at sites which indicate that the disposed munitions have or may be causing contamination of ocean waters or seabeds.

(Sec. 313) Authorizes the Secretary to transfer specified funds to the Moses Lake Wellfield Superfund Site, Washington, to reimburse the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for costs incurred in overseeing a remedial investigation and feasibility study performed by the Army.

(Sec. 314) States that the two-year limitation for cooperative agreements entered into for environmental restoration at defense facilities shall not apply when the agreement is funded out of either the Department of Defense Base Closure Account 1990 or the Department of Defense Base Closure Account 2005.

(Sec. 315) Directs the Secretary of the Air Force to: (1) conduct an analysis of the contamination and remediation costs of the Norwalk Defense Fuel Supply Point in Norwalk, California; and (2) report to Congress on analysis results.

Subtitle C: Workplace and Depot Issues - (Sec. 321) Extends through FY2014 the exclusion of certain expenditures from a percentage limitation on the contracting-out for depot-level maintenance.

(Sec. 322) Requires the Secretary of the Air Force to invest in the capital budgets of Air Force depots at least six percent of the total combined revenue of all Air Force depots for the preceding fiscal year. Allows a waiver of such minimum investment for national security reasons if such Secretary notifies the defense and appropriations committees.

(Sec. 323) Amends the Bob Stump NDAA for Fiscal Year 2003 (Stump Act) to extend through FY2008 the temporary authority to contract for increased performance of security guard functions. Requires a report from the Secretary to the defense and appropriations committees on contractor performance of security guard functions under such Act.

Subtitle D: Reports - (Sec. 331) Directs the Secretary of the Navy to report to the defense committees describing the criteria used when a nuclear attack submarine is sent to a depot maintenance facility other than a facility located within 200 miles of the homeport of the submarine when there is a public or private facility within the 200-mile homeport radius at which such maintenance could be conducted. Prohibits such Secretary, during FY2007, from conducting such maintenance at a facility other than a facility located within such 200-mile homeport radius if there is an available public or private facility at which the maintenance could be conducted without adversely affecting operational deployment schedules. Requires such Secretary to notify the defense and appropriations committees at least five days in advance of performing maintenance conducted due to operational deployment schedules.

(Sec. 332) Directs the Secretary of the Navy to report to the defense committees on the Navy's Fleet Response Plan. Requires a follow-up report from the CG containing a review of the Navy report.

(Sec. 333) Requires a report from the Secretary of the Navy to the defense committees on Navy surface ship rotational crew programs. Prohibits such Secretary from implementing any new surface ship rotational crew experiment or program during the period beginning on the date of enactment of this Act and ending on October 1, 2009. Provides for the treatment of two existing rotational crew experiments. Requires a follow-up report from the CG on an existing experiment known as the "sea swap." Requires the Director of the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) to report to the defense committees on the long-term implications of the use of crew rotations on Navy ships on the degree of forward presence provided by Navy ships.

(Sec. 334) Directs the Secretary of the Army to report to Congress on the adequacy of the live-fire Army ranges in Hawaii with respect to current and future training requirements.

(Sec. 335) Requires a report from the CG to the defense committees assessing the joint standards and protocols for access control systems at DOD installations.

(Sec. 336) Requires an initial and semiannual reports from the Secretary to specified congressional committees on future DOD requirements with respect to the Personnel Security Investigations for Industry and the National Industry Security Program of the Defense Security Service. Requires a follow-up report from the CG after the Secretary's initial report. Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) delays and backlogs associated with the Personnel Security Investigations Program (Program) threaten U.S. national security interests and key defense industrial assets; and (2) the Secretary should take necessary steps to eliminate security clearance application backlogs and make systemic improvements to the Program.

Subtitle E: Other Matters - (Sec. 341) Directs the Secretary to: (1) maintain a strategic policy on DOD programs for the prepositioning of materiel and equipment; (2) notify the defense and appropriations committees prior to implementing any policy change; and (3) establish the strategic policy within six months after the enactment of this Act.

(Sec. 342) Makes both military dogs (current law) and horses available for adoption at the end of their useful working life.

(Sec. 343) Authorizes the Secretary of the Army to carry out a program to sell recyclable munitions materials resulting from the demilitarization of conventional military munitions and to use such proceeds for the reclamation, recycling, and reuse of such munitions.

(Sec. 344) Requires the Secretary to: (1) perform an annual accounting of DOD overseas staffing requirements in order to reconcile staffing cost-sharing fees levied by the Secretary of State under the Secure Embassy Construction and Counterterrorism Act of 1999; and (2) submit to the defense and appropriations committees an annual estimate of overseas military presence.

(Sec. 345) Directs the Secretary of the Navy to: (1) ensure that financial resources are provided each fiscal year to enable the Navy to fund necessary naval mission operations, ship maintenance, combat support forces, and weapons systems support; and (2) certify annually to the defense and appropriations committees that funding requirements are satisfied for the fiscal year for which Navy O&M justification materials are submitted.

(Sec. 346) Directs the Secretary of the Army to) ensure that financial resources are provided each specified fiscal year to enable the Army to fund: (1) the repair, recapitalization, and replacement of equipment used in the Global War on Terrorism; (2) the fulfillment of equipment requirements of Army units transforming to modularity; and (3) the reconstitution of equipment and materiel in prepositioned stocks by 2012. Requires annual reporting to the defense and appropriations committees on progress toward meeting such requirements. Limits, for any fiscal year after 2007, the funds that may be expended for the Future Combat Systems until the above funding requirements are met for that fiscal year.

Title IV: Military Personnel Authorizations - Subtitle A: Active Forces - (Sec. 401) Sets forth authorized end strengths for active-duty forces as of the end of FY2007.

(Sec. 402) Revises the permanent active-duty end strength minimum levels for the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force.

(Sec. 403) Amends the Ronald W. Reagan NDAA for Fiscal Year 2005 (Reagan Act) to authorize additional increases of active-duty end strengths for the Army and Marine Corps in FY2008 and FY2009 in order to support operational missions and achieve transformational reorganization objectives.

Subtitle B: Reserve Forces - (Sec. 411) Sets forth authorized end strengths as of the end of FY2007 for members of the Selected Reserve and reserve personnel on active duty in support of the reserves.

(Sec. 413) Sets forth minimum end strengths for FY2007 for Army and Air Force dual status military technicians.

(Sec. 414) Provides a FY2007 limitation on the number of non-dual status Army and Air Force military technicians.

(Sec. 415) Provides, during FY2007, the maximum number of reserve personnel authorized to be on active duty for operational support.

Subtitle C: Authorization of Appropriations - (Sec. 421) Authorizes appropriations for FY2007 for: (1) military personnel; and (2) the Armed Forces Retirement Home.

Title V: Military Personnel Policy - Subtitle A: Officer Personnel Policy - (Sec. 501) Eliminates certain limitations concerning the counting of Navy Reserve flag officers for end strength purposes.

(Sec. 502) Requires the officer serving as the senior Air Force dental officer to be appointed in the grade of major general (currently, brigadier general).

(Sec. 503) Authorizes the Secretary of the military department concerned (Secretary concerned) to retain chief warrant officers (W-4) who have twice failed for promotion without a mandatory selective continuation board (as required under current law). Increases from 24 to 30 the years of service as a warrant officer that would require mandatory retirement.

(Sec. 504) Allows officers to be promoted to the grade of captain or lieutenant (O-3) after completing 18 months of service in the previous grade (O-2).

(Sec. 505) States that general and flag officers assigned to senior level intelligence positions within the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence shall not be subject to the supervision or control of the Secretary of Defense and shall not exercise supervision or control over DOD military or civilian personnel. Provides that an officer's appointment to such a position shall not affect the officer's status, grade, rank, compensation, rights, or benefits, and that such officer's pay and allowances shall be reimbursed to DOD from funds available to the CIA or the Office of the Director of National Intelligence.

Subtitle B: Reserve Component Management - (Sec. 511) Extends from 270 to 365 days the maximum duration of service for members of the Selected Reserve and Individual Ready Reserve called involuntarily to active duty to support operational missions. Authorizes the President to use such authority to order such personnel to active duty to provide assistance to a natural or man-made disaster, accident, or catastrophe that occurs in the United States, its territories and possessions, or Puerto Rico. Requires, in determining which members will be ordered to active duty without their consent, appropriate consideration to be given to: (1) the length and nature of previous service; (2) family responsibilities; and (3) employment necessary to maintain the national health, safety, or interest.

(Sec. 512) Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2006 to authorize military retirement credit for emergency response service performed in specified New Jersey counties immediately after the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, by members of the Army or Air National Guard.

(Sec. 513) Directs the Secretary to report to the defense committees on the promotion and constructive termination by private sector employers of members of the reserves called or ordered to active-duty service.

Subtitle C: Education and Training - (Sec. 521) Authorizes members of the Reserve Officers' Training Corps (ROTC) who participate in the Guaranteed Reserve Forces Duty scholarship program to participate in the Health Professions scholarship program and serve on active duty as required by the latter program.

(Sec. 522) Authorizes employment as Junior ROTC (JROTC) instructors for retired Reserve and National Guard members. Authorizes the Secretary concerned to determine salaries.

(Sec. 523) Authorizes professors at the U.S. Military Academy and U.S. Air Force Academy to assume command positions while on periods of sabbaticals from such Academy.

(Sec. 524) Increases from 24 to 100 the number of: (1) cadets and midshipmen at the military academies who may participate in exchange programs with foreign military academies; and (2) students from foreign military academies who may receive instruction at a U.S. military academy. Increases the annual funding for each of the military departments for such programs. Authorizes academies to use funds other than appropriated funds in support of such programs.

(Sec. 525) Directs the Secretary to: (1) conduct a review of a specified legal opinion issued by the DOD General Counsel regarding instruction of non-host unit students participating in JROTC programs; and (2) report review results to the defense committees. Allows a host school that is currently providing for the assignment of JROTC instructors to another school with 70 or more students to continue such support until 180 days following the committees' receipt of such report.

Subtitle D: General Service Authorities - (Sec. 531) Requires the Secretary to: (1) conduct a test of the utility of commercially available test preparation guides and education programs designed to assist recruit candidates to achieve scores on military recruit qualification testing that better reflect their full potential; and (2) report to the defense committees on test findings.

(Sec. 532) Prohibits the proceedings of selection boards convened for active-duty and reserve personnel actions (promotion, retention, retirement, etc.) from being disclosed to any person not a member of the board. Makes board records immune from legal process and inadmissible as evidence.

(Sec. 533) Directs the Secretary to report to the defense committees on the number of military personnel who, since September 11, 2001, have not received at least 30 days notice before a deployment that will last 180 days or more.

Subtitle E: Authorities Relating to Guard and Reserve Duty - (Sec. 542) Authorizes reserve personnel performing active Guard and reserve duty and military technicians (dual status) to also instruct or train active-duty personnel, members of foreign military forces, and DOD contractor personnel and civilian employees, as long as such instruction or training is performed in the United States, its possessions, or Puerto Rico.

(Sec. 543) Authorizes the governor of a state, Puerto Rico, or the Virgin Islands, or the commanding general of the District of Columbia National Guard, to order a member of their National Guard to perform active Guard and reserve duty, including support of operations or missions and support of training operations and missions.

(Sec. 544) Authorizes the President or a governor or commanding general described above to give authorization and consent for a National Guard officer to retain a state commission in the National Guard while serving on active duty.

(Sec. 545) Includes under the types of emergencies to which reserve personnel assigned to weapons of mass destruction civil support teams may respond to: (1) a natural or manmade disaster in the United States; or (2) the intentional or unintentional release of nuclear, biological, radiological, or toxic or poisonous chemicals in the United States that results or could result in the catastrophic loss of life or property.

Subtitle F: Decorations and Awards - (Sec. 551) Authorizes the presentation of a Medal of Honor flag to living Medal recipients or to the living next of kin of deceased Medal recipients.

(Sec. 552) Directs the Secretary to issue a Cold War Victory Medal to persons who: (1) performed active duty or inactive duty training as an enlisted member, commissioned officer, or warrant officer during the Cold War; (2) completed their initial term of enlistment, or if discharged beforehand, was honorably discharged after completing at least 180 days of active-duty service; and (3) have not received a discharge less favorable than honorable. Defines the Cold War as the period beginning on September 2, 1945, and ending on December 26, 1991.

(Sec. 553) Requires the Secretary to posthumously award the Purple Heart to a member of the Armed Forces who died in captivity as a prisoner of war or died due to illness or injury obtained while in captivity as a prisoner of war. Provides for retroactive awards for members whose deaths occurred before the date of enactment of this Act.

(Sec. 554) Directs the Secretary of the Navy to advance on the retired list of the Navy or Marine Corps retired officers who had been specifically commended for performance of duty in combat during World War II.

(Sec. 555) Requires the Secretary to: (1) review the policy, procedures, and processes of the military departments for awarding decorations to members of the Armed Forces; and (2) report review results to the defense committees.

Subtitle G: Matters Relating to Casualties - (Sec. 561) Prohibits a member with less than a 30 percent disability rating from being removed from the temporary disability retired list and separated prior to the maximum disability period allowed by law unless the disability is of a permanent nature and stable.

(Sec. 562) Authorizes the Secretary to provide assistive technology and related devices and services to a member who has sustained a severe or debilitating illness or injury while serving in support of a contingency operation.

(Sec. 563) Directs the Secretary concerned to provide transportation of the remains of a member who dies in a combat theater of operations and whose remains are returned to the United States through the mortuary facility at Dover Air Force Base, Delaware. Requires a military escort to travel with the remains.

(Sec. 564) Directs the Secretary to submit to Congress, as part of the annual defense budget request for a fiscal year, a consolidated budget justification display, in classified and unclassified form, that covers all programs and activities of DOD POW/MIA accounting and recovery organizations.

Subtitle H: Assistance to Local Educational Agencies for Defense Dependents Education - (Sec. 571) Earmarks specified defense-wide O&M funds for providing assistance to local educational agencies (LEAs) that have military dependent students comprising at least 20 percent of the students in average daily attendance during a year. Provides further assistance to LEAs that experience significant increases or decreases in average daily attendance of military dependent students due to military force structure changes, the relocation of military forces from one base to another, and base closures and realignments.

(Sec. 572) Amends the Defense Dependents' Education Act of 1978 to allow the enrollment in the defense dependents' education system of children of a foreign military member assigned to the Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers, Europe, in a school of the defense dependents' education system in Mons, Belgium.

Subtitle I: Postal Benefits - (Sec. 575) Authorizes the Secretary to provide for a program under which postal benefits (credits) shall be provided to members on active duty who are: (1) serving in Iraq or Afghanistan; or (2) hospitalized at a U.S. military facility as a result of a disease or injury incurred due to service in Iraq or Afghanistan.

(Sec. 576) Requires funding for the above postal benefits program to be paid out of funds authorized for that fiscal year for a contingent emergency reserve fund or as an emergency supplemental appropriation. Requires the Secretary to reimburse the Postal Service for such benefits.

Subtitle J: Other Matters - (Sec. 581) Reduces DOD's accrual contributions into the Department of Defense Military Retirement Fund by requiring the military department concerned to contribute at the lower, part-time rate for reserve personnel who are mobilized or serving on active duty for special work.

(Sec. 582) Eliminates the requirement for a separate dental division within the Navy Bureau of Medicine and Surgery.

(Sec. 583) Makes permanent (currently, ends December 31, 2007) DOD authority to expend appropriated funds to present recognition items for military recruitment and retention purposes.

(Sec. 584) Directs the Secretary to: (1) review the feasibility and cost-effectiveness of establishing on Guam a station to process new U.S. military recruits drawn from the western Pacific region; and (2) report review results to the defense committees.

(Sec. 585) Allows the Secretary to designate a person to administer a military enlistment or appointment oath.

(Sec. 586) Repeals the requirement for periodic DOD Inspector General assessments of voting assistance compliance at military installations.

(Sec. 587) Directs each military department Secretary to ensure, in the case of any member of the Armed Forces appearing before a physical evaluation board, that the board's decision conveys findings and conclusions with specific attention to each issue provided by the member in regard to that case. Requires the presence of physical evaluation board liaison officers to provide advice, counsel, and general information to such members on the operation of such boards. Requires the Secretary of Defense to assess military department compliance with such requirements, as well as with standards and guidelines for board training and staff, at least every three years.

(Sec. 588) Directs the Secretary to: (1) require participation by eligible military personnel in the Department of Labor's employment, job training, and other transitional assistance following discharge or release from active duty; and (2) encourage and promote such participation for members who have previously participated in the program and members returning to positions of employment or pursuing academic degrees or other occupational objectives. Makes certain reserve personnel eligible for the program.

(Sec. 589) Revises the formula by which government contributions are made to the Medicare-Eligible Uniformed Services Retiree Health Care Fund (for the financing of health care for military retirees who are also eligible for health care under Medicare). Makes the Secretary of Defense (currently, the Secretary of the Treasury) responsible for making annual accrual payments into the Fund. Excludes, for purposes of the formula: (1) cadets and midshipmen at service academies; and (2) certain reserve personnel who are not counted against active-duty end strengths. Bases reserve personnel numbers on the number of members of the Selected Reserve (smaller) rather than the Ready Reserve.

(Sec. 590) Gives chaplains in each of the military departments the prerogative to pray according to the dictates of the chaplain's own conscience, except as must be limited by military necessity, with any such limitation being imposed in the least restrictive manner feasible.

(Sec. 591) Directs the Secretary to report to the defense committees on personnel requirements for airborne assets identified as low-density, high-demand airborne assets based on combatant commander requirements to conduct and sustain operations for the global war on terrorism.

(Sec. 592) Requires the Secretary to establish a task force to provide input to the Secretary and the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) for improving DOD and SBA programs to address the economic concerns, as well as business challenges and opportunities, of entrepreneurial service members. Requires a task force report to the Secretary and the Administrator on its findings and recommendations. Terminates the task force on September 30, 2009.

(Sec. 593) Directs the CG to report to Congress concerning the frequency and consequences of members of the Armed Forces claiming status as military conscientious objector between January 1, 1989, and December 31, 2006.

(Sec. 594) Amends the Reagan Act to extend by six additional months the Commission on the National Guard and Reserves. Provides additional matters to be reviewed by the Commission. Requires an additional Commission report to the defense committees.

Title VI: Compensation and Other Personnel Benefits - Subtitle A: Pay and Allowances - (Sec. 601) Waives any FY2007 pay increases tied to increases in the General Schedule of Compensation for government employees. Increases, effective January 1, 2007, by 2.7 percent the rates of basic pay for military personnel.

(Sec. 602) Revises, effective April 1, 2007, the rates of basic pay within each pay grade for commissioned officers, warrant officers, and enlisted personnel.

(Sec. 603) Increases maximum pay levels for general and flag officers to reflect increases in maximum salaries for Senior Executive Service personnel.

(Sec. 604) Authorizes the Secretary concerned to provide a second basic allowance for housing (BAH) to reserve members without dependents mobilized in support of a contingency operation and serving in a location that does not allow the member to reside at their permanent residence.

(Sec. 605) Authorizes the spouse of a member who dies while serving on active duty to receive a BAH for up to 365 days after the date of the member's death, even though the spouse is also a member of the Armed Forces.

(Sec. 606) States that the prohibition barring reserve personnel from receiving compensation for work or study performed in a correspondence course shall apply to any work or study performed on or after September 7, 1962, and includes members of the National Guard while not in federal service.

(Sec. 607) Requires the Secretary concerned to pay the full premium (currently, only the premium required for the first $150,000 worth of coverage ) for coverage under the Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance (SGLI) program for members serving in Operations Enduring Freedom or Iraqi Freedom. Provides a funding source for the additional premiums.

Subtitle B: Bonuses and Special and Incentive Pays - (Sec. 611) Extends through 2007 specified authorities currently scheduled to expire at the end of 2006 with respect to certain special pay and bonus programs within the regular and reserve Armed Forces.

(Sec. 615) Allows military dentists to be paid additional special pay while also receiving variable special pay for participation in internship or residency programs.

(Sec. 616) Increases from $10,000 to $25,000 the maximum annual special pay for Selected Reserve health care professionals serving in critically short wartime specialties.

(Sec. 617) Allows the payment of nuclear officer incentive pay as a lump sum or in variable annual amounts in addition to payment in equal annual installments.

(Sec. 618) Increases from: (1) $20,000 to $30,000 the maximum nuclear career accession bonus; and (2) $2,500 to $10,000 the maximum incentive bonus for transfer between the Armed Forces due to a shortage of trained and qualified personnel.

(Sec. 620) Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2006 to include, under a bonus payment program for referring other persons for enlistment into the Army, members of a reserve component under 60 years of age who, but for such age, would be eligible for military retired pay.

(Sec. 621) Authorizes the Secretary to carry out a pilot program for the payment of a recruitment incentive bonus in order to improve recruitment for critical health care specialties. Limits the program to two years, 100 participants, and no more than five critical medical specialties. Requires a program mid-term and final report from the Secretary to the defense committees.

(Sec. 622) Expands the temporary program of voluntary separation pay and benefits for members voluntarily separated from active duty to: (1) remove the participation prohibition for enlisted personnel and officers with between 12 and 20 years of service; and (2) extend such program through December 31, 2009.

(Sec. 623) Authorizes the Secretary to pay a bonus to a retired member of the regular or reserve Armed Forces who executes an agreement to serve on active duty in an assignment intended to alleviate a high-demand, low-density military capability or in any other specialty designated as critical to meet wartime or peacetime requirements. Limits the bonus to $50,000. Authorizes the Secretary to develop and provide additional incentives to encourage such members to return to active duty in such assignments. Requires the Secretary to report to the defense committees describing such incentives at least 30 days before offering the incentives. Requires bonus repayment by members failing to serve the agreed-upon period. Terminates the program after December 31, 2010. Authorizes the Secretary of a military department to order to active duty a member who agrees to such an assignment, with the same deadline date. Limits to $5 million the FY2007 obligations that may be incurred for the bonus program.

Subtitle C: Travel and Transportation Allowances - (Sec. 631) Authorizes the Secretary concerned to pay costs associated with the delivery of a motor vehicle to a storage location selected by a member, as long as such costs do not exceed the costs that would have been incurred at a storage location approved by the Secretary concerned.

(Sec. 632) Authorizes members with at least one other driver-eligible family member to ship, at government expense, two privately-owned vehicles during a permanent change of station move to nonforeign duty locations outside the continental United States.

(Sec. 633) Includes family members who are also military members under the authority to pay for the travel and transportation of family members to visit ill or injured military personnel.

Subtitle D: Retired Pay and Survivor Benefits - (Sec. 641) Authorizes a participant in the Survivor Benefit Plan (SBP), in the case of the death of the chosen beneficiary, to elect a new beneficiary within 180 days after the death of the previous beneficiary. Outlines provisions concerning the change in premium after election of the new beneficiary.

(Sec. 642) Authorizes the payment of an additional $150,000 death gratuity for survivors of members who died during non-combat duty during the period from May 12, 2005, through August 31, 2005. Provides funding for such additional payments.

(Sec. 643) Allows the retired pay for a member of the reserves to be calculated using the member's total years of service, as opposed to active-duty years of service, when the retirement involves a disability incurred under circumstances for which the member is awarded the Purple Heart.

Subtitle E: Commissary and Nonappropriated Fund Instrumentality Benefits - (Sec. 651) States that, for products sold at commissary or exchange stores at a surcharge above the normal five-percent-over-cost (items such as tobacco products, disposable cameras, film, and telephone calling cards), the surcharge shall be applied to the surcharge fund as if it were a uniform surcharge product.

(Sec. 652) Prohibits contracts for ancillary services on property leased by DOD to private entities if the Secretary concerned determines that those services will be provided in direct competition with exchanges, commissaries, or morale, welfare, and recreation activities.

(Sec. 653) Allows the Secretary to authorize the use of nonappropriated funds to supplement or replace appropriated funds for the construction of facilities of the exchange stores system and other nonappropriated fund instrumentalities, military lodging facilities, and community facilities used to supplement mission activities. Requires a report from the Secretary to the defense and appropriations committees concerning the use of such funds for such purposes.

(Sec. 654) Requires a report from the Secretary to Congress on the cost-effectiveness of purchasing commercial insurance for commissary and exchange facilities and facilities of other morale, welfare, and recreation programs and nonappropriated fund instrumentalities.

Subtitle F: Other Matters - (Sec. 661) Repeals a required annual report from the Secretary to Congress on the effects of recruitment and retention initiatives.

(Sec. 662) Directs the Secretary to conduct a pilot project at not less than three military golf courses to evaluate the cost-effectiveness and utility of making available golf carts that are accessible for disabled persons, and to evaluate the demand for such carts among disabled persons authorized to use such courses. Requires: (1) the pilot project to be conducted for at least one year; and (2) a report from the Secretary to Congress on project results.

(Sec. 663) Increases from one to five years following an honorable discharge or separation from service the period during which the Secretary concerned may remit or cancel indebtedness of members who incurred such indebtedness during active duty.

Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2006 to extend through 2009 the termination date of the temporary authority of the military department secretaries to remit or cancel indebtedness of members.

Title VII: Health Care Provisions - Subtitle A: TRICARE Program Improvements - (Sec. 701) Provides coverage under TRICARE (a DOD managed care program) for forensic examinations following sexual assault or domestic violence.

(Sec. 702) Authorizes TRICARE coverage for anesthesia services and costs in connection with dental treatment for patients with developmental, mental, or physical disabilities, and for children under five years of age.

(Sec. 703) Updates terms related to TRICARE primary and preventive health care services for women to include cervical and breast cancer screening.

(Sec. 704) Prohibits DOD from increasing the premium, deductible, copayment, or other charge for TRICARE Prime, the charge of inpatient care for TRICARE Standard, and the premium for TRICARE Reserve Select and TRICARE Standard for members of the Selected Reserve during the period from April 1, 2006, to December 31, 2007.

(Sec. 705) Allows mental health counselors, without prior physician referral or supervision, to be reimbursed for services provided to TRICARE beneficiaries.

Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 1995 to allow mental health counselors to enter into personal services contracts with DOD for the provision of mental health services to TRICARE beneficiaries.

(Sec. 706) Directs the Secretary to conduct a demonstration project to allow particular over-the-counter medications to be included on the DOD uniform formulary (in lieu of equivalent prescription drugs). Requires a project report from the Secretary to the defense committees.

(Sec. 707) Allows a TRICARE for Life beneficiary to be reimbursed for travel expenses to a military medical facility if: (1) the travel is for a follow-up appointment for medical treatment of a condition; and (2) the initial appointment was at the same facility. Allows such reimbursement: (1) for no more than three follow-up appointments; and (2) only if adequate follow-up medical treatment cannot be obtained within 100 miles of the residence of the beneficiary.

(Sec. 708) Directs the Secretary, beginning in FY2007, to annually adjust for inflation the TRICARE children's hospital differential payment rate.

(Sec. 709) Provides TRICARE Standard coverage to members of the Selected Reserve and their families while such members are in a non-active duty status.

(Sec. 710) Extends to the TRICARE program the same rule applicable under the Medicare program that prohibits an employer or other entity from offering any financial or other incentive for a TRICARE retired beneficiary not to enroll under a group health plan which would be the primary payer to TRICARE. Authorizes the Secretary to exclude an employer or other entity from any contract to provide goods or services to, or receive financial assistance from, DOD for repeated violations of such prohibition.

Subtitle B: Studies and Reports - (Sec. 711) Directs the Secretary to establish within DOD a task force to: (1) examine matters relating to the future of military health care; (2) report to the Secretary an assessment of, and recommendations for, sustaining the military health care services being provided to members of the Armed Forces, retirees, and their families; and (3) submit a final report to the Secretary on its activities. Terminates the task force 90 days after the final report.

(Sec. 712) Requires the Secretary to: (1) conduct a study of providing chiropractic health care services to members on active duty and their dependents, and members entitled to military retired pay and their dependents; (2) revise the plan required under the Floyd D. Spence NDAA for Fiscal Year 2001 (Spence Act) to provide chiropractic health care services and benefits as a permanent part of the Defense Health Program; and (3) report to the defense committees on study results.

(Sec. 713) Directs the CG to study, and report to the defense committees on, projected cost savings to the Defense Health Program included in the FY2007 budget request.

(Sec. 714) Provides for the transfer to the Medical Follow-up Agency of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences of data and biological specimens related to the current Air Force Health Study commonly known as the Ranch Hand Study. Requires a report from the Secretary of the Air Force to the defense committees on such transfer.

(Sec. 715) Requires the Secretary to study and report to the defense committees on the feasibility of allowing family members of reserve personnel who are called or ordered to active duty to continue health care coverage under a civilian health care program and to provide reimbursement for such health care.

Subtitle C: Other Matters - (Sec. 721) Establishes as unallowable contract costs that result when DOD contractors pay or otherwise create financial incentives for TRICARE-eligible employees to use the TRICARE or other government-sponsored health care programs in lieu of the contractor-provided health care program.

(Sec. 722) Directs the Secretary to develop a program requiring each military department to include training for health care professionals under their jurisdiction in the preservation of remains.

Subtitle D: Pharmacy Benefits Program Improvements - (Sec. 731) Requires the Secretary to establish beneficiary cost-sharing requirements for the TRICARE mail order pharmacy program that are the same as requirements for generic and formulary drugs provided to beneficiaries at military treatment facilities. Provides cost-sharing limits for generic, formulary, and nonformulary drugs. Terminates such cost-sharing requirements on December 31, 2007.

Title VIII: Acquisition Policy, Acquisition Management, and Related Matters - Subtitle A: Provisions Relating to Major Defense Acquisition Programs - (Sec. 801) Directs the Under Secretary to: (1) develop a training program to certify civilian and military personnel of DOD with responsibility for generating requirements for major defense acquisition programs (MDAPs); and (2) establish competency requirements for personnel undergoing the training program.

(Sec. 802) Requires: (1) the Secretary to establish regulations to ensure that an MDAP developed with federal or private funds acquires sufficient technical data to allow competition for contracts required for sustainment of the MDAP; and (2) any contract for an MDAP to include price and delivery options for acquiring major elements of technical data not acquired at the time of initial contract award. Directs the Under Secretary to ensure that members of the acquisition workforce working with any contract in excess of $5 million and involving the acquisition of rights in technical data are provided information and formal training to carry out the requirements of this section.

(Sec. 803) Directs the Secretary to: (1) conduct a study on revisions to requirements relating to Selected Acquisition Reports; and (2) report to the defense committees on study results.

(Sec. 804) Requires the Secretary to provide an update to the defense committees on the implementation of plans to reform the DOD acquisition system.

(Sec. 805) Establishes requirements for Defense Acquisition Challenge Program proposals solicited in response to a critical cost growth threshold breach for an MDAP. Requires the Under Secretary, in the case of such a breach, to issue a solicitation for challenge proposals that would result in improvements in affordability of the MDAP. Outlines solicitation and challenge proposal requirements, as well as authorized actions upon favorable and unfavorable full review and evaluation of challenge proposals for critical cost breaches.

(Sec. 806) Requires, before an MDAP may proceed to Milestone B, certification that market research has been conducted prior to technology development to reduce duplication of existing technology and products.

Subtitle B: Acquisition Policy and Management - (Sec. 812) Prohibits the Secretary from entering into a contract for the procurement of goods or services from any foreign person to which the government of a foreign country that is a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) has provided a subsidy if: (1) the United States has requested consultations with that foreign country on the basis that the subsidy is prohibited; and (2) either the issue before the WTO has not been resolved or the WTO has ruled that the subsidy is a prohibited subsidy. Makes such prohibition inapplicable to any contract under an MDAP that has received Milestone B approval.

(Sec. 813) Prohibits the DOD executive or milestone decision authority entity for a DOD information technology business system that is not a national security system from providing Milestone A approval for the system unless, as part of the approval decision, the executive or authority determines that the system will achieve initial operational capability within five years of such approval.

(Sec. 814) Directs the Secretary to establish the Panel on Contracting Integrity to: (1) conduct reviews of DOD progress to eliminate areas of vulnerability of the defense contracting system that allow fraud, waste, and abuse; (2) review a required CG report relating to areas of vulnerability in DOD contracts; and (3) recommend changes in law and policy necessary to eliminate such areas of vulnerability. Requires annual reports from the Panel to the defense and appropriations committees.

Subtitle C: Amendments to General Contracting Authorities, Procedures, and Limitations - (Sec. 821) Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2004 to extend through FY2007 the special temporary DOD authority to close out certain contracts entered prior to October 1, 1996.

(Sec. 822) Prohibits the Secretary from entering into a contract for certain covered services needed for performing the contract if the amount of the contract: (1) exceeds 75 percent of the estimated value of any asset required for the provision of services under the contract; or (2) exceeds $150 million in payments over the life of the contract assuming all options to extend the contract are exercised. Authorizes the Secretary to waive the prohibition for national security purposes, after prior notification to the defense and appropriations committees.

(Sec. 823) Authorizes the Administrator of the General Services Administration (GSA) to allow state or local governments to use GSA federal supply schedules for goods and services to facilitate recovery from natural disasters, terrorism, or nuclear, biological, chemical, or radiological attack.

(Sec. 824) Allows an executive agency to issue a waiver to extend a task order contract for up to ten additional years if the head of the agency determines in writing that: (1) the contract provides engineering or technical services so unique that award of a new contract would be harmful to the continuity of the program for which the services are performed; (2) award of a new contract would create a large disruption in services provided to the agency; and (3) the agency would endure program risk during critical program stages due to loss of corporate knowledge of ongoing program activities. Requires a report from the Secretary to the defense committees on advisory and assistance services. Prohibits the issuance of any waiver under this section until such report is submitted.

(Sec. 825) Amends the Contract Disputes Act of 1978 to provide for the expedited disposition, by the Armed Forces Board of Contract Appeals and the Civilian Board of Contract Appeals, of appeals of small businesses where the amount in dispute is $150,000 or less.

(Sec. 826) Includes Hispanic-serving institutions within DOD contracting goals for small disadvantaged businesses and certain institutions of higher education.

(Sec. 827) Directs the Secretary to require that any contract entered into or renewed by DOD include a provision prohibiting the contractor from requiring toy and hobby manufacturers, distributors, or merchants to obtain licenses from or pay fees to the contractor for the use of military likenesses or designations on items provided under the contract.

Subtitle D: United States Defense Industrial Base Provisions - (Sec. 831) Prohibits funds appropriated or otherwise made available to DOD from being used for the procurement of a specialty metal or an item critical to national security (as determined by the Strategic Materials Protection Board, established in this Subtitle) if that metal or item is not reprocessed, reused, or produced in the United States. Provides exceptions, including: (1) when satisfactory quality and sufficient quantity cannot be procured as and when needed; (2) procurements outside the United States in support of combat or contingency operations; and (3) when necessary to comply with trade agreements with foreign governments. Makes the prohibition inapplicable to: (1) items purchased for resale in commissaries, exchanges, and nonappropriated fund instrumentalities operated by DOD; and (2) procurements in amounts not greater than the simplified acquisition threshold. Authorizes a one-time inadvertent micropurchase (defined under the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act) waiver of a specialty metals procurement in the case of a contract with DOD in effect before the enactment of this Act, requiring the Secretary concerned to approve the waiver. Allows for a 15-day challenge period with respect to the one-time waiver.

(Sec. 832) Requires the Secretary to establish a Strategic Materials Protection Board to, among other things: (1) determine the need to provide a long-term domestic supply of items designated as critical to national security; (2) recommend a strategy to the President to ensure the domestic availability of designated critical items; and (3) publish in the Federal Register, at least every two years, a list of designated items, including critical specialty metals. Prohibits the Board from removing an item from the designated critical list until 30 days after notifying the defense and appropriations committees.

Title IX: Department of Defense Organization and Management - Subtitle A: Department of Defense Management - (Sec. 901) Standardizes the definition of "national security system" within various laws applicable to DOD.

(Sec. 902) Makes a technical change to reflect the current name of the Defense Information Systems Agency.

(Sec. 903) Adds the commander of the U.S. Strategic Command to the membership of the Nuclear Weapons Council.

(Sec. 904) Consolidates the management of Department of Defense Regional Centers for Security Studies (currently operated under various authorities). Allows the Centers to pursue bilateral and multilateral research, communication, and exchange of ideas involving U.S. military and civilian personnel. Permits foreign governments and U.S. federal agencies to fund foreign participation in Center activities. Authorizes the Secretary to waive reimbursement of costs of activities for military officers and civilian defense and security officials from developing countries. Continues an annual reporting requirement from the Secretary to the defense committees on the operation of the Centers, with additional reporting requirements.

(Sec. 905) Redesignates the: (1) Department of the Navy as the Department of the Navy and Marine Corps; and (2) Secretary of the Navy as the Secretary of the Navy and Marine Corps. Makes equivalent changes to related statutory positions.

Subtitle B: Space Activities - (Sec. 911) Amends the Commercial Space Transportation Competitiveness Act of 2000 to make conforming changes to reflect the organizational structure of the National Space-Based Positioning, Navigation, and Timing Executive Committee (which replaced the Interagency Global Positioning Executive Board).

(Sec. 912) Extends through FY2009 the authority of the Secretary to conduct a pilot program of providing to non-U.S. government entities certain space surveillance data support.

(Sec. 913) Directs the Secretary to establish within DOD the Operationally Responsive Space Program Office to contribute to the development of low-cost, rapid reaction payloads, spacelift, and launch control capabilities in order to fulfill joint military operational requirements for on-demand space support or reconstitution. Requires the Secretary to: (1) ensure that there is a separate DOD budget program element for operationally responsive national security payloads and buses of DOD for space satellites; and (2) submit to the defense and appropriations committees a plan for the DOD acquisition of capabilities for operationally responsive space to support the warfighter.

Subtitle C: Chemical Demilitarization Program - (Sec. 921) Amends the Strom Thurmond NDAA for Fiscal Year 1999 (Thurmond Act) to transfer from the Under Secretary to the Secretary of the Army program management responsibility for the Assembled Chemical Weapons Alternatives program. Requires such Secretary to continue the implementation of previously selected alternative technologies in carrying out the destruction of lethal chemical munitions at the Pueblo Chemical Depot, Colorado, and the Blue Grass Army Depot, Kentucky.

(Sec. 922) Directs the CG to submit to Congress a review of a cost-benefit analysis prepared by the Secretary of the Army concerning off-site versus on-site treatment and disposal of hydrolysate derived from the neutralization of VX nerve gas at the Newport Chemical Depot, Indiana.

(Sec. 923) Expresses the sense of Congress that when chemical munitions or processed chemical munitions are proposed for treatment or disposal at a location remote from the location where the munitions are stored: (1) the method of selecting the disposal location should be free from political interference; and (2) a process like that used for selecting and approving military installations for closure or realignment should be considered.

Subtitle D: Intelligence-Related Matters - (Sec. 931) Repeals the December 31, 2006, termination of the authority of the Secretary to engage in commercial activities as security for intelligence collection activities abroad.

Title X: General Provisions - Subtitle A: Financial Matters - (Sec. 1001) Authorizes the Secretary, in the national interest, to transfer up to $3.75 billion of the amounts made available to DOD in this Act between any such authorizations for that fiscal year, with limitations. Requires congressional notification of each transfer.

(Sec. 1002) Adjusts amounts authorized to be appropriated to DOD and the Department of Energy (DOE) in the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2006 by the amount by which appropriations pursuant to such authorizations are increased pursuant to an emergency supplemental appropriations Act for 2006.

(Sec. 1003) Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2006 to increase its FY2006 general transfer authority.

(Sec. 1004) Provides the total amount to be contributed by the Secretary in FY2007 for the common-funded budgets of NATO (rather than the maximum amount otherwise applicable under the FY1998 baseline limitation).

(Sec. 1005) Requires a report from the Secretary to the defense committees on the fuel rate and cost projection used in the annual DOD budget presentation.

(Sec. 1006) Reduces by $1.583 billion the total amount authorized to be appropriated in titles I through III of this Act, to be derived from savings resulting from lower-than-expected inflation.

Subtitle B: Policy Relating to Vessels and Shipyards - (Sec. 1011) Authorizes the Secretary, in undertaking a vessel disposal or the disposal of a class of vessels, to dispose of another vessel or class of vessels if the substituted vessel(s) has (have) virtually identical capabilities.

(Sec. 1012) Includes, for purposes of the prohibition against the overhaul, repair, or maintenance in a foreign shipyard of a U.S. military vessel, any Military Sealift Command vessels that are owned or chartered under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of the Navy. Revises the definition of "emergency voyage repair" for purposes of such requirement.

(Sec. 1013) Requires: (1) the Secretary of the Navy to report to the defense committees on future lease options available with respect to the Guam Shipyard; and (2) the CG to evaluate the report and report results to such committees. Requires such Secretary, for FY2007, to award to the Guam Shipyard contracts equal to the average contracts awarded for FY1998 through FY2006 for the purpose of maintaining the industrial base in case of a national emergency or to achieve industrial mobilization.

(Sec. 1014) Directs the Secretary of the Navy to establish the Shipbuilding Industrial Base Improvement Program, under which such Secretary: (1) makes grants to facilitate the development of innovative design and production technologies and processes for naval vessel construction and the development of modernized shipbuilding infrastructure; and (2) provides loan guarantees to facilitate the acquisition by shipyards of technologies, processes, and infrastructure to improve their productivity and cost-effectiveness. Limits federal funds to 75 percent of the total cost, with exceptions for small projects. Provides loan guarantee limits. Directs such Secretary to conduct periodic assessments to discover and correct Program inefficiencies. Provides Program funding.

(Sec. 1015) Requires the Secretary of the Navy to enter into an agreement with the Commandant of the Coast Guard for the transfer to the Coast Guard of operational control of not less than five Cyclone-class patrol coastal ships for a period extending at least through September 30, 2012.

(Sec. 1016) Prohibits a military department Secretary from contracting for the lease or charter of a vessel for a term of more than 24 months if its hull or component thereof is constructed in a foreign shipyard. Authorizes the President to waive such prohibition for national security purposes (with congressional notification).

(Sec. 1017) Prohibits the Secretary from awarding any contract for the carriage by vessel of cargo for DOD unless the contract requires the contractor to: (1) ensure that all overhaul, repair, and maintenance performed on the vessel during the contract period is performed in a U.S. shipyard; or (2) report to the Secretary every fiscal quarter on all overhaul, repair, and maintenance performed on the vessel in a non-U.S. shipyard during the contract period.

(Sec. 1018) Prohibits the Secretary from awarding any charter of a vessel for DOD, or contracting for the carriage of cargo by vessel for DOD, unless the charter or contract requires that each riding gang (crew) member that performs work on the vessel during that period holds a merchant mariner's document issued under U.S. maritime administration laws. Allows exemptions by the Secretary with respect to the performance of specific technical work on original equipment of a vessel.

Subtitle C: Counter-Drug Activities - (Sec. 1021) Codifies under federal Armed Forces law provisions of the NDAA for Fiscal Year 1991 and the NDAA for Fiscal Year 1998 authorizing DOD to provide support for counter-drug activities of federal, state, local, and foreign law enforcement agencies, as well as certain foreign governments. Expands the foreign governments authorized for such support to include Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Guatemala, Belize, and Panama. Authorizes, in connection with such support: (1) the transfer of specified nonlethal equipment; (2) for FY2007 and FY2008, the provision of crew-served weapons of .50 caliber or less to the government of Afghanistan; and (3) additional expenditures for FY2007 and FY2008.

(Sec. 1023) Amends the Reagan Act to extend through FY2008 its authority to support a unified counterdrug and counterterrorism campaign in Colombia.

(Sec. 1024) Amends the Spence Act to extend by one year a reporting requirement regarding DOD expenditures to support foreign counter-drug activities.

(Sec. 1025) Requires a report from the Secretary to the defense and appropriations committees updating the interagency counter-narcotics implementation plan for Afghanistan and the South and Central Asian regions, as originally required under the NDAA for Fiscal Year 1998.

Subtitle D: Other Matters - (Sec. 1031) Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2006 to: (1) extend through 2025 the nuclear stockpile assessment period for the Commission on the Implementation of the New Strategic Posture of the United States; and (2) revise Commission reporting dates.

(Sec. 1032) Increases from $2,500 to $10,000 the maximum award, for assistance in combating terrorism, that may be delegated by a commander of a combatant command. Expands the senior officers to whom such award authority may be delegated.

(Sec. 1033) Requires a report from: (1) the Secretary to the defense committees on the findings of a specified semiannual assessment process relating to the Global War on Terrorism; (2) the President to Congress on improving interagency support for 21st century national security missions; and (3) the Secretary to the defense committees (quarterly) on the implementation of recommendations described in the DOD 2006 Quadrennial Defense Review Report.

(Sec. 1036) Directs the Secretary to ensure that current members of the Armed Forces, retired members, disabled veterans, and persons assisting disabled veterans are able to utilize lands under DOD jurisdiction that are available for hunting or fishing. Requires an assessment of such lands from the Secretary to Congress.

Requires the Secretary of the Interior to immediately cease a plan to exterminate by helicopter the deer and elk on Santa Rosa Island, California.

(Sec. 1038) Directs the Secretary to ensure that a database containing specified response and support capabilities is maintained by DOD.

(Sec. 1039) Amends the Reagan Act to expand the information required in an annual report relating to investigations or prosecutions regarding the treatment of individuals detained by U.S. Armed Forces or by a person providing contract services to DOD.

(Sec. 1040) Extends the final report of the Commission to Assess the Threat to the United States from Electromagnetic Pulse (EMP) Attack from June 30, 2007, to 18 months after commencement of Commission activities.

Title XI: Civilian Personnel Matters - (Sec. 1101) Increases from 594 to 644 the authorized number of Defense Intelligence Senior Executive Service employees in FY2007.

(Sec. 1102) Includes civilian employees under DOD authority to pay the full replacement value of household goods damaged or lost during transportation at government expense.

(Sec. 1103) Authorizes the accrual of annual leave for members performing dual (military and civilian) employment.

(Sec. 1104) Directs the United States to pay a death gratuity of $100,000 to the survivors of a federal employee who dies of injuries incurred in connection with service with an armed force in a contingency operation, or in connection with a terrorist incident during service with an armed force. Provides for retroactive payment of such gratuity with respect to an employee who dies on or after October 7, 2001, in the performance of duty in Operations Enduring Freedom or Iraqi Freedom. Defines eligible survivors.

Title XII: Matters Relating to Foreign Nations - Subtitle A: Assistance and Training - (Sec. 1201) Authorizes the Secretary, with the concurrence of the Secretary of State, to provide logistic support, supplies, and services to allied forces participating in a combined operation with U.S. Armed Forces. Limits to $100 million the total value of such support in a fiscal year.

(Sec. 1202) Authorizes the Secretary to use DOD acquisition and cross-servicing agreements to lend certain military equipment to foreign forces in Iraq and Afghanistan for personnel protection and survivability purposes. Limits the loan duration to one year. Directs the Secretary to submit semiannual reports to the defense and foreign relations committees on the use of such authority. Terminates such authority on September 30, 2008.

(Sec. 1203) Codifies under federal Armed Forces law provisions relating to the DOD humanitarian demining assistance program. Authorizes the Secretary concerned to provide such assistance if it will promote either: (1) the security interests of both the United States and the country in which the assistance is carried out; or (2) the specific operational readiness skills of military personnel participating in the program.

(Sec. 1204) Renames the Regional Defense Counterterrorism Fellowship Program as the Regional Defense Combating Terrorism Fellowship Program. Increases from $20 million to $25 million the annual obligation limit under the Program. Allows the obligation of funds across fiscal years.

(Sec. 1205) Requires the Secretary to direct the National Defense University to ensure that visits to China and Taiwan are an integral part of its field study programs, and that the field study programs include at least one trip annually to each of those countries.

(Sec. 1206) Directs the Secretary to undertake a program of senior military officer and senior military official exchanges with Taiwan designed to improve Taiwan's defenses against the People's Liberation Army of the People's Republic of China.

Subtitle B: Nonproliferation Matters and Countries of Concern - (Sec. 1211) Prohibits the Secretary from purchasing goods or services from any entity that knowingly transfers an item that is on the United States Munitions List to the People's Republic of China. Requires the Secretary to annually publish a list of any foreign persons sanctioned for such a transfer, and allows the Secretary to remove a person from such list only after a five-year prohibition period. Provides exceptions.

Subtitle C: Other Matters - (Sec. 1221) States that it is U.S. policy to make available to Taiwan plans and options for design and construction work on future diesel electric submarines under the U.S. foreign military sales process. Requires a report from the Secretary to the defense and appropriations committees on present and future Navy efforts to execute the President's policy to sell diesel electric submarines to the Republic of China on Taiwan.

Title XIII: Cooperative Threat Reduction With States of the Former Soviet Union - (Sec. 1301) Specifies the cooperative threat reduction (CTR) programs to be funded through O&M funds provided under this Act. Makes funds appropriated for such purpose available for three years. Allocates such funds among specified CTR programs. Prohibits such funds from being used for purposes other than those specified until 30 days after the Secretary reports to Congress on the new purposes. Provides limited authority to vary allocated amounts in the national interest, after congressional notification.

(Sec. 1303) Amends the Reagan Act to extend, until completion of the facility, the President's authority to waive certain funding restrictions during the construction of a chemical weapons destruction facility in Russia. Directs the Secretary to notify Congress of the date of completion.

(Sec. 1304) Directs the Secretary to: (1) enter into an arrangement with the National Academy of Sciences under which the Academy carries out a study of lessons learned, past and present challenges, and possible options in managing and facilitating threat reduction and nonproliferation projects under the CTR program; and (2) report study results to the defense committees.

Title XIV: Homeland Defense Technology Transfer - Homeland Defense Technology Transfer Act of 2006 - Authorizes the Secretary to create a Homeland Defense Technology Transfer Consortium to improve the speed and effectiveness of identifying, evaluating, deploying, and transferring to federal, state, and local first responders DOD technology items and equipment in support of homeland security as required under the Stump Act. Outlines related Consortium duties. Requires: (1) an annual Consortium activities report to the President and Congress; and (2) an annual report from the Secretary to Congress on DOD activities to identify, test and evaluate, or develop technologies with application to federal, state, and local first responders. Authorizes appropriations.

Title XV: Authorization for Increased Costs Due to Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom - (Sec. 1501) Authorizes emergency supplemental appropriations to DOD for FY2007, for additional costs due to Operations Iraqi Freedom and Enduring Freedom, for: (1) procurement; (2) RDT&E; (3) O&M; (4) the Defense Health Program; (5) classified programs; and (6) military personnel.

(Sec. 1512) Authorizes the Secretary, in the national interest, to transfer amounts made available in this title for FY2007 between any such authorizations for that fiscal year, with a total transfer limit of $3 billion. Requires prior transfer notification to the defense and appropriations committees.

Division B: Military Construction Authorizations - Joel Hefley Military Construction Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2007 - Title I: Army - (Sec. 2101) Authorizes the Secretary of the Army to acquire real property and carry out military construction projects in specified amounts at specified installations and locations. Authorizes such Secretary to construct or acquire family housing units, carry out architectural planning and design activities, and improve existing military family housing in specified amounts. Authorizes appropriations to the Army for fiscal years after 2006 for military construction, land acquisition, and military family housing functions of the Army. Limits the total cost of construction projects authorized by this title.

Title II: Navy - (Sec. 2201) Provides, with respect to the Navy, authorizations paralleling those provided for the Army under the previous title.

(Sec. 2205) Amends the Military Construction Authorization Act (MCAA) for Fiscal Year 2004 and the MCAA for Fiscal Year 2005 to consolidate authority for the construction of an outlying landing field in Washington County, North Carolina.

Title III: Air Force - (Sec. 2301) Provides, with respect to the Air Force, authorizations paralleling those provided for the Army under Title I of this Division.

Title IV: Defense Agencies - (Sec. 2401) Authorizes the Secretary to acquire real property and carry out military construction projects in specified amounts at specified installations and locations. Authorizes the Secretary to construct or acquire family housing units, carry out architectural planning and design activities, and carry out certain energy conservation projects.

(Sec. 2404) Authorizes the Secretary to carry out base closure and realignment activities, including real property acquisition and military construction projects, as authorized by the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 and funded through the Department of Defense Base Closure Account 2005. Limits the total cost of such activities. Prohibits the obligation of funds for such activities until after a conditional period following notification of the defense and appropriations committees.

(Sec. 2405) Authorizes appropriations to DOD for fiscal years after 2006 for military construction, land acquisition, and military family housing functions of DOD. Limits the total cost of construction projects authorized by this title.

(Sec. 2406) Amends the MCAA for Fiscal Year 2006 to increase the amounts authorized for National Security Agency (NSA) construction projects in: (1) Augusta, Georgia; (2) Kunia, Hawaii; and (3) Menwith Hall, United Kingdom.

Title V: North Atlantic Treaty Organization Security Investment Program - (Sec. 2501) Authorizes the Secretary to make contributions for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) Security Investment Program and authorizes appropriations for fiscal years after 2006 for such Program.
